image.altText: Portrait of Yoorrook Commissioner Sue-Anne Hunter

items.synopsis: In its most significant proposal yet, Victoria’s Indigenous truth-telling commission takes aim at the child protection and criminal justice systems it says are failing First Peoples.

title.children: Powerful Aboriginal truth-telling body lays down 46 recommendations for change in Victoria

image.altText: Young girl with a fluffy dog, laying in a white bed with a bandage around her head.

items.synopsis: When Fiona Elsey's mother was going through old mementos she'd kept since her daughter's death, she came across the teen's handwriting unexpectedly. What she read made her cry.

title.children: Fiona died from cancer at 14. Her mum recently found a letter she wrote in the back of a colouring book

image.altText: A man looking at a destroyed vehicle near a road.

items.synopsis: Progress in Ukraine's counteroffensive has been slower than expected, but its forces are building momentum in the country's south, and could be just 15 kilometres away from a major prize.

title.children: Why Ukraine could be just 15km from forcing Putin to make an impossible choice

image.altText: A young boy in a spiderman suit opens his mouth excitedly, facing just off camera.

items.synopsis: The foster mother of missing boy William Tyrrell has pleaded guilty to assaulting a child in her care in incidents that occurred two years ago.

title.children: William Tyrrell foster mother pleads guilty to assaulting a child

image.altText: Men kneel down while aiming black semi-automatic firearms in a corrugated iron shed.

items.synopsis: A leading opposition MP in Solomon Islands is calling for an independent investigation into a contentious shipment of "replica weapons" brought into the Pacific Island country by China after publicly released US diplomatic cables claimed the guns were likely real.

title.children: 'Were we told the truth?': Chinese 'replica' guns in Solomon Islands likely real, US cable says

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair wearing a dark blazer answers questions from a reporter in a corridor.

items.synopsis: Nationals Senator Bridget McKenzie will push for an inquiry, saying many Australians are disappointed with a decision to block Qatar Airways from adding extra direct flights to major ports.

title.children: Senate may probe government's rejection of more Qatar flights

image.altText: A qantas plane taking off into a clear blue sky with a city skyline at the bottom in the distance

items.synopsis: August was meant to be the month where Qantas would prove it had done the impossible after the pandemic devastated the airline. Instead, it spent a week embroiled in controversies that won't be Alan Joyce's responsibility to clean up.

title.children: After a turbulent week with a $570m price tag, Qantas says it's 'absolutely determined' to fix its battered reputation

image.altText: Several Bottles of RoundUp on the shelf

items.synopsis: A class action involving 800 Australians who allege their non-Hodgkin lymphoma was caused by Roundup has begun in Melbourne.

title.children: Class action begins alleging one of the world's most popular weedkillers causes cancer

image.altText: Russell Broadbent speaks at a lecturn in the house of representatives

items.synopsis: Russell Broadbent says he changed his mind about how he would vote after being contacted First Nations people in his Victorian electorate.

title.children: Veteran Liberal MP backtracks on support for yes vote in Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum

image.altText: A motorcycle lying on its side.

items.synopsis: Police investigate a collision involving off-road motorcycles that claimed the lives of two teenagers in Melbourne's outer north-west.

title.children: 'Recipe for disaster': Police say teenagers killed in Melbourne motorcycle crash were unlicensed

image.altText: Small white button mushrooms growing in soil.

items.synopsis: Supermarkets are telling their mushroom suppliers that sales have decreased by up to 10 per cent in the past few weeks. It comes in the wake of three people dying of suspected death cap mushroom poisoning in Gippsland, Victoria.

title.children: Mushroom sales fall after suspected poisoning at Leongatha lunch

image.altText: A man wearing a beekeeper suit sanding in front of beehives.

items.synopsis: After playing a crucial role in pollinating Victorian almond orchards and a week caught in a varroa mite surveillance zone, Queensland's Murray Arkadieff and his 1,000 beehives are finally heading home.

title.children: Murray's 100 million bees are finally on the move after an 'anxious' week stuck in a varroa mite surveillance zone

image.altText: a man wearing a cap looking at the camera and smiling

items.synopsis: The alleged driver involved in a fatal crash involving two siblings in south-west Sydney has posted himself eating a fast food meal allegedly before handing himself in to police.

title.children: Accused driver of crash that killed two siblings filmed himself eating KFC allegedly before going to police

image.altText: Sandy beach foreshore in early morning. Wind-blown palm trees, empty children's playground & two people on boardwalk in distance

items.synopsis: A West Australian man has been arrested after he allegedly attempted to drown a boy at the Dampier Foreshore this morning.

title.children: Man arrested after allegedly attempting to drown 5yo at WA beach

image.altText: The chair of ASIC, James Shipton, during a press conference.

items.synopsis: If this matter wasn't so serious, Treasury's responses to former ASIC chairman James Shipton's letters about his experience at the regulator would make rich material for an episode of the British political satire Yes Minister, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Former ASIC boss said his job led him to despair. What shocked him the most was the government response

image.altText: Yellow curtains dangle above a blue floor in a flash-photograph.

items.synopsis: A yellow curtain and black fireplace may hold the key to cracking cold cases into child exploitation and abuse, while victims go unreported.

title.children: 'Needle in a haystack': Federal police release images inside child abuse rooms

image.altText: A blonde white woman wearing a blue and white striped halter-neck and matching headband drives a bright pink car.

items.synopsis: Greta Gerwig's Barbie has broken another record, becoming the highest-grossing film of the year as the ongoing actors and writers' strike continues to halt Hollywood.

title.children: Barbie dethrones The Super Mario Bros. Movie to become the year's highest-grossing film

image.altText: Grace Hyland in a car looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: An Australian transgender content creator has spoken out after her before and after transition photos were used in a preview clip for Channel Seven's program Spotlight, in an episode about children who regret transitioning, without her consent.

title.children: 'I don't regret it at all': Transgender content creator claims Channel 7 used her photos without consent

image.altText: A composite image shows the three marines in side-by-side images

items.synopsis: The bodies of the three marines who died when their MV-22B Osprey aircraft crashed on Melville Island are expected to be repatriated to the United States today after a military ramp ceremony.

title.children: Bodies of US marines killed in Osprey crash to be farewelled before repatriation flight

image.altText: A young man sitting on his desk.

items.synopsis: Gold Coast councillor Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden, who has been charged with the murder of his stepfather, has been asked by the Queensland Local Government Minister to explain why he should not be suspended with full pay.

title.children: Councillor accused of murder asked to explain why he should not be suspended with pay

image.altText: A close-up shot of a woman giving an intense and focused smile.

items.synopsis: Jessica Camilleri had her sentence extended by 22 months for assaulting two prison officers, and will be eligible for parole in 2032.

title.children: Woman who decapitated mother has sentence extended after ripping hair off prison officers

image.altText: Giant magpie sculpture beside a gold coin featuring the magpie.

items.synopsis: Just 18 months after swooping into Canberra, a giant magpie is being recognised as one of the nation's top 'big things' on new $1 coins from the Royal Australian Mint.

title.children: Chip-loving magpie swoops in to join Australia's top 'big things' on new collectible coins

image.altText: A truck on its side with its wheels in the air and road blocked off.

items.synopsis: The truck driver was taken to the hospital with minor injuries, while some injured cattle had to be euthanised.

title.children: Livestock truck crashes into house, people urged to look out for wandering cattle

image.altText: Two brunette women sit on the floor of a lounge room looking at each other smiling while patting a dog that lay on the ground

items.synopsis: Erica Packer, former wife of billionaire James Packer, opens up about the deadly genetic mystery shadowing her family and the scientists working to crack the code for thousands more Australians.

title.children: Why a family legacy means Erica Packer goes through life fearing constant 'Russian roulette'

image.altText: an image of a middle aged woman with brown hair wearing a coloured shirt

items.synopsis: It's the most common genetic disorder in Australia that leaves people tired and lethargic, but you've probably never heard of it.

title.children: Denise was fighting daily exhaustion and pain. Giving blood was the answer

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Local shares make gains at open with company profits, inventories, and wages data due mid-morning. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX higher, Liontown soars on Albemarle offer, NZ casino Skycity faces suspension

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasury Wine said on Monday that Stuart Boxer had been appointed as its chief financial and strategy officer, effective November 1. Mr Boxer succeeds Matt Young, who had been the group's CFO since 2018. Mr Boxer, who is currently serving as the country's largest winemaker's chief strategy and corporate development officer, will combine his existing responsibilities with the new CFO responsibilities, the company added in a statement. Treasury Wine said it would benefit from Mr Boxer's strong experience in the financial, strategy and M & A areas. Prior to joining Treasury Wines, Mr Boxer served as the CFO and executive general manager strategy at DuluxGroup for a little more than a decade. The Melbourne-headquartered company had last month appointed John Mullen as its chairman, succeeding Paul Rayner who was retiring from the company's board.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasury Wine appoints new CFO

children.content: Treasury Wine said on Monday that Stuart Boxer had been appointed as its chief financial and strategy officer, effective November 1.
Mr Boxer succeeds Matt Young, who had been the group's CFO since 2018.

Mr Boxer, who is currently serving as the country's largest winemaker's chief strategy and corporate development officer, will combine his existing responsibilities with the new CFO responsibilities, the company added in a statement.
Treasury Wine said it would benefit from Mr Boxer's strong experience in the financial, strategy and M
A areas.
Prior to joining Treasury Wines, Mr Boxer served as the CFO and executive general manager strategy at DuluxGroup for a little more than a decade.
The Melbourne-headquartered company had last month appointed John Mullen as its chairman, succeeding Paul Rayner who was retiring from the company's board.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares has climbed ahead of a likely pause in interest rate hikes by the Reserve Bank. The ASX 200 rose 0.4 per cent to 7,310 by 12:24pm AEST. The RBA is expected to keep its key interest rate unchanged at 4.10 per cent on Tuesday as inflation shows signs of easing, according to a Reuters poll of economists, who do however largely expect a final hike next quarter. Miners jumped 1.5 per cent to touch their highest level since mid August, tracking gains in iron ore prices. Mining heavyweight BHP said it had received approval from a Brazilian court for a reorganisation plan for its Samarco joint venture, sending its shares up as much as 2.4 per cent. Energy stocks rose 1.3 per cent to hit their highest level in two weeks. Santos added 1.3 per cent, while Woodside Energy inched up 1.4 per cent. Banks logged a 0.1 per cent gain.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still tracking higher at lunch

children.content: Australian shares has climbed ahead of a likely pause in interest rate hikes by the Reserve Bank.
The ASX 200 rose 0.4 per cent to 7,310 by 12:24pm AEST.
The RBA is expected to keep its key interest rate unchanged at 4.10 per cent on Tuesday
as inflation shows signs of easing, according to a Reuters poll of economists, who do however largely expect a final hike next quarter.
Miners
jumped 1.5 per cent to touch their highest level since mid August, tracking gains in iron ore prices.
Mining heavyweight
BHP
said it had received approval from a Brazilian court for a reorganisation plan for its Samarco joint venture, sending its shares up as much as 2.4 per cent.
Energy stocks
rose 1.3 per cent to hit their highest level in two weeks. Santos added 1.3 per cent, while Woodside Energy inched up 1.4 per cent.
Banks
logged a 0.1 per cent gain.
Top movers at lunch
(Reuters)
Bottom movers at lunch
(Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Qantas has made a statement to the ASX in response to the consumer watchdog's legal action against the airline. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) alleges Qantas advertised and sold tickets for thousands of flights that it had already cancelled but not removed from sale. It alleges Qantas sold tickets for flights that were scheduled to depart between May and July 2022, but which had been cancelled, and that it kept selling tickets for those flights on its website for an average of more than two weeks, and in some cases for more than a month. It also alleges that, for more than 10,000 flights set to take off between May and July 2022, the airline failed to notify ticketholders that their flights had been cancelled for an average of 18 days. Qantas said the period of time that the ACCC’s claims relate to was one of well-publicised upheaval and 
uncertainty across the aviation industry. "We openly acknowledges "that our service standards fell well short and we sincerely apologise. We have worked hard to fix them since 
and that work continues," the airline said in the statement on Monday. "The ACCC’s allegations come at a time when Qantas’ reputation has already been hit hard on several fronts". "We want the community to know that we hear and understand their disappointment. We know that the only 
way to fix it is by delivering consistently. We know it will take time to repair. And we are absolutely determined 
to do that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas responds to ACCC legal action

children.content: Qantas has made a statement to the ASX in response to the consumer watchdog's legal action against the airline.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) alleges Qantas advertised and sold tickets for thousands of flights that it had already cancelled but not removed from sale.

It alleges Qantas sold tickets for flights that were scheduled to depart between May and July 2022, but which had been cancelled, and that it kept selling tickets for those flights on its website for an average of more than two weeks, and in some cases for more than a month.

It also alleges that, for more than 10,000 flights set to take off between May and July 2022, the airline failed to notify ticketholders that their flights had been cancelled for an average of 18 days.
Qantas said the period of time that the ACCC’s claims relate to

was one of well-publicised upheaval and 
uncertainty across the aviation industry.

"We openly acknowledges "that our service standards fell well short and we sincerely apologise. We have worked hard to fix them since 
and that work continues," the airline said in the statement on Monday.
"The ACCC’s allegations come at a time when Qantas’ reputation has already been hit hard on several fronts".

"We want the community to know that we hear and understand their disappointment. We know that the only 
way to fix it is by delivering consistently. We know it will take time to repair. And we are absolutely determined 
to do that."

image.altText: A group of people outdoors standing around bricks and a green rug.

items.synopsis: Algeria says its security forces opened fire after a group of jet skiers from Morocco ignored warning shots and refused to comply with orders to stop.

title.children: Algeria says jet skiers killed by coastguard unit ignored warning shots, as families plan to launch legal action

image.altText: A group of men wearing blue shirts and a group wearing red shirts throw things at each other around a building corner

items.synopsis: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu floats a plan to see all African migrants deported after a clash between Eritrean factions on the streets of Tel Aviv.

title.children: Israel's PM wants to deport Eritrean migrants involved in violent clash

image.altText: Man in royal outfit and crown

items.synopsis: With the one-year anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II's death approaching, royal fans took to Buckingham Palace to commemorate with a parade of her favourite breed of dogs.

title.children: 'Can't see a better way to remember her': Corgis dress in royal best for late queen
